qas.question: What is the dominant scheme for internal processing?
What is Unicode available through Windows on?
What was the two-byte precursor to UTF-16?
What is used almost exclusively for building new information processing systems?
What are legacy encodings used exclusively for?
What was the precursor to the UCS-2?

plausible_answers.text: Windows 2000, Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7

qas.question: What descended from Mac OS X?
What are Mac OS X and KDE called?

context: <a0_0>Unicode<a0_0/> has become the dominant scheme for internal processing and storage of text. Although a great deal of text is still stored in legacy encodings, <a3_0>Unicode<a3_0/> is used almost exclusively for <b4_0>building new information processing systems<b4_0/>. Early adopters tended to use <a2_0><b8_0>UCS-2<b8_0/><a2_0/> (the fixed-width two-byte precursor to <b5_0>UTF-16<b5_0/>) and later moved to UTF-16 (the variable-width current standard), as this was the least disruptive way to add support for non-BMP characters. The best known such system is Windows NT (and its descendants, <b6_0>Windows 2000, Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7<b6_0/>), which uses UTF-16 as the sole internal character encoding. The Java and .NET <b7_0>bytecode environments<b7_0/>, Mac OS X, and KDE also use it for internal representation. Unicode is available on Windows 95 through <a1_0>Microsoft Layer<a1_0/> for Unicode, as well as on its descendants, Windows 98 and Windows ME.
